title: Difference between successor corporation and alter ego?
question: Alter ego liability seems to be focused on shareholders, while successor corporation seems more just that the new company is a continuation of the previous company.
answers: I deal in the world of mergers and acquisitions. In my field, when one company succeeds to the rights and obligations of another, through a corporate purchase, for example, that company is the successor corporation. If you run your company in such a way that there is no real separation between your business affairs and your personal life, the company can be deemed your "alter ego" meaning that, from a legal point of view, there is no difference between you and it. This often happens where a business owner pays all his personal expenses through the company. If your company is deemed to be your alter ego, this is bad, because it means creditors can attack your personal assets, even if you claim they belong to the corporation, because you have failed to maintain any distinction between what belongs to your business and your personal assets.

There is a difference, although sometimes they are treated as synonyms, and oftentimes a case that involves one also involves the other.

Alter ego liability is also known as piercing the corporate veil. It is a legal theory under which the shareholders of a corporation can be held liable for the acts and debts of the corporation they own, notwithstanding that generally shareholders are protected from those liabilities. It typically applies where the shareholders have ignored the corporate formalities and have generally treated the corporation's affairs as their affairs and have run both personal and corporate matters through the corporation, such as using the corporate bank accounts for personal use, using corporate property for personal use without reimbursing the corporation for that use, and the like.

Successor liability is a legal theory under which one entity becomes liable for the debts and obligations of another entity. It can arise on purpose, such as when one corporation expressly assumes the debts/obligations of the other - in which case successor liability was intended - or as the result of a transfer of assets and activities that is essentially tantamount to a merger or consolidation of the two corporations, or where the new corporation essentially picks up where the old corporation left off, retaining all of the old contacts, employees, etc, or where the transfer of assets, business, and etc. from one to the other was done for the purpose of fraudulently escaping a debt or other liability.

Alter ego and successor issues are often intertwined where one individual uses multiple corporations, one after the other, to rack up debts and then attempt to avoid them, and mixes personal business with corporate business - frequently the point of using multiple corporations this way is to engage in personal activities without the concomitant responsibilities that go along with them.

I completely agree with Mr. Doland - these are completely separate concepts which apply in different situations (although it is possible that there might be some overlap).
Successor liability deals with the liability, or potential liability, a purchaser of the corporation's stock or, in certain circumstances, all or substantially all of the corporation's assets with a continuation of the corporation's operations, and the purchaser assumes or is imputed with liabilities arising from the pre-purchase operations.
Alter ego is an equitable concept applied to avoid unjust and unfair results from the use of a corporate shell to improperly avoid liability for a shareholder or shareholders. It is applied in limited circumstances, as the entire premise of creating a corporation is to limit the liability of the shareholders for the operations, etc of the corporation. It is a complex concept, and while it may be often asserted or claimed, it is not often successful in litigation as the proof of the elements necessary is difficult.

Totally different. When one corporation purchases all or the majority of the shares of another corporation the liability associated with the old corporation pass to the new. There are scenarios where purchase of assets by one corporation from another not accompanied by the bulk sales procedure may impose liability of the buying corporation for debt associated with those assets.

Alter ego alleges that one single corporation, not two corporations, is a sham and that the shareholder(s) are treating the corporation and the owners as two pockets in the same pair of pants, with no observance corporate formalities and putting money into either pocket as if they were the same. It says the corporation is set up and run so defectively that the protection of the entity should not apply to this corporation or this/these owners.
